p.salute: Dear ladies and gentlemen of the Ministry of Education,

p.s: I recently learned that you have takenShakespeare out of the English school curriculum.
I am now writing this letter to urge you to rethink that decision.
I believe there are an abundance of reasons as to whyShakespeare should be dealt with in school (a personal reason being that his work is simply beautiful).
Firstly, one can notcannot ignore ShakespearesShakespeare's incredible influence in modern English literature and all kinds of other arts, such as rap.
EndAnd it is also undeniable that he is still very present, 400 years after his death.
He has been translated into many different languages and his work is embedded into many cuturescultures.
One of them being the germanGerman culture, there is still a statue ofShakespeare standing in Weimar and his plays are still presented in germanyGermany all of the time.
Therefore, takingShakespeare out of the curriculum would mean a great loss in the education of students.

And to those who may see his work is old, confusing and outdated, I retort that his unique way of describing human nature and human experiences such as love, pain and fear, can never be outdated, because he manages to describe universal emotions in a way that makes the reader feel seen and undestoodunderstood.
And the need for being understood and not feeling alone is timeless and so is ShakespearesShakespeare's work.
I ask you to consider my arguments and to please let students of further generations experience the joy of reading and learning about Shakespeare.

p.signed: With kind regards, a student in Cologne
